content.title: Central Venous Access
content.summary: Central venous catheter (CVC) placement is essential for ICU patients requiring vasopressors, TPN, multiple infusions, or reliable access. Site selection (internal jugular, subclavian, femoral) balances infection risk, procedural complications, and patient factors. Ultrasound guidance is now standard of care for IJ and femoral lines, reducing complications. CLABSI prevention uses bundled approaches: chlorhexidine prep, maximal barrier precautions, daily necessity review, and prompt removal when no longer needed.
key_points: Indications: Vasopressors, TPN, multiple incompatible infusions, no peripheral access, hemodynamic monitoring
Ultrasound guidance mandatory for IJ; reduces complications 50%
Subclavian: Lowest infection rate but highest pneumothorax risk
IJ: Moderate infection risk; lowest pneumothorax; US-guided preferred
Femoral: Easiest in emergencies; highest infection risk; avoid if possible
CLABSI bundle: CHG prep, max barriers, optimal site, daily review, prompt removal
content.statement: Central venous access provides reliable vascular access for critical care interventions, with site selection based on clinical context, mandatory ultrasound guidance for IJ lines, and strict CLABSI prevention bundles reducing catheter-related infections.

explanation.intuition: A central line is like a highway directly into the large central veins - it can handle medications that would damage smaller peripheral veins (like vasopressors) and provides reliable, long-lasting access. The challenge is getting in safely and keeping it clean.
explanation.key_insight: Ultrasound has been transformative. Real-time visualization reduces arterial punctures by 50%, speeds up insertion, and reduces complications. It's now standard of care for IJ lines. The days of 'landmark only' technique should be over for internal jugular access.
explanation.technical_details: Seldinger technique: Needle access → guidewire → dilator → catheter. Confirm venous placement with manometry, blood gas, or ultrasound before dilation. Standard catheter lengths: IJ 15-17 cm, subclavian 15-17 cm, femoral 20-25 cm. Tip should be at cavoatrial junction or lower SVC. Confirm placement with CXR post-procedure.

definitions_glossary.central_venous_catheter: Catheter placed in large central vein (IJ, subclavian, femoral) for access
definitions_glossary.internal_jugular: IJ vein; lateral to carotid; preferred site for most ICU patients
definitions_glossary.subclavian_vein: Under clavicle; lowest infection rate but pneumothorax risk
definitions_glossary.femoral_vein: Groin; easiest access but highest infection rate
definitions_glossary.chlorhexidine: CHG; antiseptic for skin prep; superior to povidone-iodine
definitions_glossary.maximal_barrier_precautions: Cap, mask, sterile gown, gloves, full drape
definitions_glossary.manometry: Measuring pressure to confirm venous (not arterial) access
definitions_glossary.guidewire: Flexible wire threaded through needle for catheter placement
definitions_glossary.ultrasound_guidance: Real-time visualization of vessel during cannulation
definitions_glossary.cavoatrial_junction: SVC-right atrium junction; optimal catheter tip location

internal_jugular.anatomy: Lateral to carotid artery; within SCM triangle
internal_jugular.preferred_when: Most ICU situations; default first choice

subclavian.anatomy: Under clavicle; junction of subclavian and IJ
subclavian.preferred_when: Long-term access; ambulatory patients; low coagulopathy

femoral.anatomy: Groin; medial to femoral artery (NAVEL mnemonic)
femoral.preferred_when: Emergency access; coagulopathy; cannot access above diaphragm

preparation.max_barriers: Cap, mask, sterile gown, sterile gloves, full-body drape

ultrasound_guidance.technique: Visualize vein compressibility; confirm needle in vein before wire
ultrasound_guidance.benefit: Reduces arterial puncture, hematoma, attempts, time

Seldinger_steps: Needle access into vein (confirm venous blood return)
Pass guidewire through needle (should advance easily)
Make skin nick at wire entry
Remove dilator, advance catheter over wire
Remove wire (NEVER lose control of wire)

confirmation.post_procedure: Chest X-ray for IJ/subclavian to confirm tip position and rule out pneumothorax

arterial_puncture.management: Remove needle/catheter, direct pressure; if dilated, vascular surgery

thrombosis.prophylaxis: Remove when not needed; consider anticoagulation

insertion_bundle.max_barriers: Full sterile barriers for everyone in room
insertion_bundle.daily_necessity: Ask every day if line still needed

maintenance_bundle.dressing: CHG-impregnated dressing; change every 7 days or if soiled
maintenance_bundle.daily_review: Remove promptly when no longer needed

definition.@value: Placement of catheter in central vein for medication administration, monitoring, or venous access

scopeNote.@value: Ultrasound guidance now standard for IJ; CLABSI bundle essential

medicalCode.description: Insertion of infusion device into superior vena cava

learning_objectives: Select appropriate CVC site based on clinical context
clinical_pearls: Ultrasound guidance reduces IJ complications by 50% - now standard of care
Subclavian has lowest infection rate but highest pneumothorax risk
Femoral is easiest but has highest infection rate - avoid if possible
NEVER lose control of the guidewire - fatal complication if lost
Ask daily: does this patient still need this central line?
common_misconceptions: Landmark technique is acceptable for IJ - US is now standard
Femoral is equivalent to IJ - higher infection rate
Dark blood confirms venous access - arterial blood can appear dark; use manometry

citations.authors: Parienti JJ, Mongardon N, Mégarbane B, et al.
citations.title: Intravascular Complications of Central Venous Catheterization by Insertion Site

evidence.confidence_rationale: High-quality RCT evidence and established guidelines
